newsitem.title: INDIA: India sees fiscal deficit cut to 4 pct in 2/3 yrs.
newsitem.headline: India sees fiscal deficit cut to 4 pct in 2/3 yrs.

text.p: India's fiscal deficit would be brought down to four percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the next two to three years, Finance Minister P. Chidambaram said on Tuesday.

"This year, we have estimated the fiscal deficit at 5.0 percent and it may take two to three years to bring it down to below 4.0 percent," a Finance Ministry statement quoted Chidambaram saying at a meeting of state ministers.
India's fiscal deficit in 1995/96 (April-March) stood at 5.9 percent.
Chidambaram said that the first task of the government was to contain fiscal deficit.
He said financing of deficits through borrowing would raise inflation and keep interest rates at high levels.
"The high cost of borrowing is also reflected in the central government's fiscal deficit," Chidambaram said.
He said that the level of subsidies in the economy was high and urged for a more prudent approach on that front.
The government has promised to prepare a comprehensive paper on subsidies, both open and hidden, and submit it to parliament in the next session.
Chidambaram ruled out further government guarantees to private power producers to ensure payment obligations of state-run electricity boards who would buy power from private generation companies.
"I also believe that we can get at least $ 7.0 billion over the next five years if we can introduce reforms in the power sector including state electricity boards (and) distribution," he said.
